column4: Is it possible to reserve some memory to be used for 'new' applications?
not sure what you mean
Considering I have 4 GB of RAM, and am not using Unity, that's kinda sad.
that's not correct behavior. either you simply *are* maxed out, and you need to keep fewer programs open (or use swap), or there is a bug.
what does "free" report?
Note that I did close an ubuntu 11.10 VM, which was using ~1GB.
But even with that running, I should of had significantly more RAM available .
hm pastebin the output of "ps aux" then
http://pastie.org/3201410
I had looked through that, but didn't see any obvious problems.

yeah me neither, but i think the sums are correct. if you sum all the RSS from your processes, the result is 1698189. that, plus 802752 of cache, is  about 2500000, and your used memory is only slightly above that
so really, the stuff *is* taking up all that memory, and there's not much you can do about it
do you have any swap? it could help (or it could make things thrash, i dunno)
I do. Barely any of it's used though, because RAM is available :)
I don't think ps is including the 'freeable' RAM.

what do you mean by freeable RAM? VSZ is what the processes have allocated - and it's *not* really assigned to physical memory until it's needed. RSS is what actually needed to be written into memory.
I was under the impression the OS expands to fill as much memory as possible, to limit the required amount of disk accessess.
yes, it does, that's the "cache", but that's *already* freed automatically (or swapped out) when required
it's those 800mb "free" is reporting
but, if that "cache" is still at 800mb (or still high, anyway) after you try to run Eclipse and it fails, then something is wrong.
Thanks for trying.
